articles.headline: At Estée Lauder, a Brand Is Developed Just for China
articles.snippet: The cosmetics company plans to sell a skin care brand called Osiao that caters to the tastes of consumers in Asia.
articles.abstract: The cosmetics company plans to sell a skin care brand called Osiao that caters to the tastes of consumers in Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: How does an American-based company make deeper inroads in China after it has already introduced some of its popular, long-established brands?

articles.headline: I.M.F.’s Call for More Cuts Irks Greece
articles.snippet: Greeks are increasingly angry over the prospect that public salaries and pensions will be sharply cut again in a last-ditch bid to secure a 31.5-billion-euro loan installment.
articles.abstract: Greeks are increasingly angry over the prospect that public salaries and pensions will be sharply cut again in a last-ditch bid to secure a 31.5-billion-euro loan installment.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As Greece enters a pivotal week in its economic crisis, tensions between the Greek government and the country’s international lenders have reached a boiling point. The government is resisting a push by the International Monetary Fund to impose additional austerity measures that Greek leaders fear could destabilize the shaky coalition government.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Amid Criticism, CNN Defends Reporting on Ambassador’s Journal
articles.snippet: The State Department said CNN violated an agreement with J. Christopher Stevens’s family.
articles.abstract: The State Department said CNN violated an agreement with J. Christopher Stevens’s family.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite a third day of vociferous criticism from the State Department, CNN executives on Monday strongly defended the decision to base some of their reporting about Libya on the private diary of J. Christopher Stevens, the ambassador who was slain in an attack on the United States consulate in Benghazi on Sept. 11.

articles.headline: Spain Recoils as Its Hungry Forage Trash Bins for a Next Meal
articles.snippet: As the economy worsens, some residents of Spain are turning to garbage bins in search of discarded food.
articles.abstract: As the economy worsens, some residents of Spain are turning to garbage bins in search of discarded food.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — On a recent evening, a hip-looking young woman was sorting through a stack of crates outside a fruit and vegetable store here in the working-class neighborhood of Vallecas as it shut down for the night.

articles.headline: U.S. Warning to Hospitals on Medicare Bill Abuses
articles.snippet: The Obama administration cited “troubling signs” of abuse from the use of electronic records and vowed to prosecute fraud cases.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration cited “troubling signs” of abuse from the use of electronic records and vowed to prosecute fraud cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saying there are “troubling indications” of abuse in the way hospitals use electronic records to bill for Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement, the Obama administration warned on Monday that it would not tolerate what it called attempts to “game the system” and vowed to vigorously prosecute doctors and hospitals implicated in fraud.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Big Law Steps Into Uncertain Times
articles.snippet: The importance of lawyers has never been greater, yet the legal industry has come under great pressure. One result may be a change in the business model.
articles.abstract: The importance of lawyers has never been greater, yet the legal industry has come under great pressure. One result may be a change in the business model.
articles.lead_paragraph: The legal profession sits at the nexus of dealmakers’ worlds, from Wall Street to Silicon Valley to Washington. As regulations change and the threat of litigation rises, the importance of lawyers has never been greater.

articles.headline: In Arab Spring, Obama Finds a Sharp Test
articles.snippet: In the almost two years of political turmoil in the Arab world, President Obama has learned that bold words and support for democratic aspirations are not enough to engender good will in the region.
articles.abstract: In the almost two years of political turmoil in the Arab world, President Obama has learned that bold words and support for democratic aspirations are not enough to engender good will in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Hosni Mubarak did not even wait for President Obama’s words to be translated before he shot back.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Robert F. Worth

articles.headline: About-Face for Bankers’ New Lobbyist
articles.snippet: To say that the choice of Tim Pawlenty to represent the banking industry is odd would be an understatement, but his appointment is the clearest sign yet of the flexible ethic that makes the revolving door in Washington spin faster.
articles.abstract: To say that the choice of Tim Pawlenty to represent the banking industry is odd would be an understatement, but his appointment is the clearest sign yet of the flexible ethic that makes the revolving door in Washington spin faster.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I went to Wall Street and told them to get their snout out of the trough because they are some of the worst offenders when it comes to bailouts and carve-outs and special deals.”

articles.headline: Riot at Foxconn Factory Underscores Rift in China
articles.snippet: Analysts say the nation’s workers have become more aware of their rights but have few outlets to challenge or negotiate with employers.
articles.abstract: Analysts say the nation’s workers have become more aware of their rights but have few outlets to challenge or negotiate with employers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The images and video began to appear on Chinese social networking sites early Monday: buildings with shattered windows, overturned police cars, huge crowds of young people milling about in the dark and riot police in formation.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Safer Flights, but Risk Lurks on the Runway
articles.snippet: About 1,000 times a year, a plane or a vehicle moves onto an active runway by mistake, and regulators have been slow to address the problem.
articles.abstract: About 1,000 times a year, a plane or a vehicle moves onto an active runway by mistake, and regulators have been slow to address the problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: Southwest Airways Flight 844 from Minneapolis had just landed at Chicago’s Midway International Airport last December and was about to cross a runway on its way to the terminal when the co-pilot noticed a business jet barreling toward him. He shouted for the captain to stop. The plane, carrying 74 passengers, screeched to a halt just short of the runway as the smaller jet crossed before their eyes.

articles.headline: Syrian War’s Spillover Threatens a Fragile Iraq
articles.snippet: Syria’s civil war is straining sectarian tensions in Iraq nine months after American forces left, and it is causing Iraq’s Shiite-led government to move closer to Iran.
articles.abstract: Syria’s civil war is straining sectarian tensions in Iraq nine months after American forces left, and it is causing Iraq’s Shiite-led government to move closer to Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The civil war in Syria is testing Iraq’s fragile society and fledgling democracy, worsening sectarian tensions, pushing Iraq closer to Iran and highlighting security shortcomings just nine months after American forces ended their long and costly occupation here.

articles.headline: Obama Tells U.N. New Democracies Need Free Speech
articles.snippet: President Obama used his last major address on a global stage before the November election to deliver a defense of freedom of speech, challenging fledgling democracies to ensure that right.
articles.abstract: President Obama used his last major address on a global stage before the November election to deliver a defense of freedom of speech, challenging fledgling democracies to ensure that right.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — President Obama on Tuesday used his last major address on a global stage before the November election to deliver a strong defense of America’s belief in freedom of speech, challenging fledgling Arab and North African democracies to ensure that right even in the face of violence.

articles.headline: Home Prices Rise Again, This Time on the Low End
articles.snippet: The housing market is still gathering strength, new data showed, and the gains appear to be spreading even to the cheapest homes in many cities.
articles.abstract: The housing market is still gathering strength, new data showed, and the gains appear to be spreading even to the cheapest homes in many cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: The housing market continues to gather strength, and the biggest gains in price now appear to be among the least expensive homes, whose values fell the most in the downturn and have weighed against any would-be recovery.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Nelson D. Schwartz
